Problem:
Consider a scalar linear time-invariant (LTI) system represented by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = kx\\), where k is a real constant. The Laplace transform of x(t) is used to obtain the transfer function, and various filters represented by transfer functions \\(H(s) = \\frac{1}{s+p}\\) are applied, where p is a pole introduced by the filter.

If at t = t_1, an additional filter with a different pole q is applied, will the output \\(x(T)\\) for T > t_1 be solely determined by the original system dynamics (constant k) and not by any filter properties (poles p or q)?
Explanation: The addition of another filter introduces a new dynamic element into the system. The output \\(x(T)\\) will depend on the interaction of both filters with the LTI system, reflecting the effects of both poles p and q along with the system's inherent dynamics represented by k. This compound effect alters the trajectory from what would be produced by just the underlying system.
